_header: Sith that ye list to be my hostess
_description: Death’s Warning to the World — eight stanzas rhyme royal; partly from The Fall of Princes (1904), I.764-70, 806-12, 918-24, 925-31, 960-66.

BodDou322.First Lines:
Syth that ye lyste to be my costesAnd in youre book to set myne
                    Image…
BodDou322.Last Lines:
…That in thys worlde euery lyuyng creatureffor Adams synne
                    must dye of nature
BodDou322.Attributed Author:
Thyese balades that thus ben wryten here be take owte of the book of Iohn
                    Lucas and sayde to the peple that shall see thys lytell tretyse in tyme to come
                    (f. 20ra)
BodDou322.Editions:
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.
EETS
         o.s. 192 (1934); repr. 1961: 2.655-57.
Wager,  Willis J. 
             “Two Poems from the ‘Booke of John Lucas.’” 
             Philological Quarterly
         15 (1936): 377-83: 377-83 (extracts).

CULFf545.First Lines:
Seth þat þe list to be myn hostesseAnd in youre boke to
                    sette myn ymage…
CULFf545.Last Lines:
…That in this worlde eche liuyng creatureffor Adames synne
                    must die of nature
CULFf545.Attributed Title: Dictamen vel lugubre carmen terribilissimi Mortis (f. 13)

BLHar1706.First Lines: Syth that ye lyste to be my costysAnd in youre boke to sett my ymage…
BLHar1706.Last Lines: …That in thys worlde eny lyuyng creatureffor Adams synne must dye of nature
BLHar1706.Note: In a loose rhyme, abab; preceded by a drawing of a skeleton with “deth” written on and around it (f. 19va).
